supporting.text: French is the official language of France, a major European country, and is widely spoken there.

attacks.text: French is the official language of France, a major European country, and is widely spoken there.
Not all European countries have French as an official or widely spoken language.
Many Europeans speak languages other than French, such as German, Spanish, or Italian.
France is just one of many European countries, and its linguistic practices do not represent the entire continent.
The diversity of languages in Europe is well-documented, with many countries having their own official languages.

supporting.text: French is one of the official languages of the European Union, indicating its prominence in Europe.

attacks.text: French is one of the official languages of the European Union, indicating its prominence in Europe.
Not all European countries are members of the European Union, so the EU's official languages do not represent all of Europe.
Many Europeans speak languages other than French, such as German, Spanish, or Italian, as their primary language.
The European Union's official languages include multiple languages, not just French, showing linguistic diversity.
Even within EU member states, French is not universally spoken; regional languages dominate in many areas.
The EU's multilingual policy promotes equality among its official languages, preventing any single language from dominating.

supporting.text: Many Europeans learn French as a second language due to its cultural and diplomatic importance.

attacks.text: Many Europeans learn French as a second language due to its cultural and diplomatic importance.
Not all European countries prioritize French as a second language; some focus on English or other languages.
Learning a language as a second language does not imply fluency or everyday usage.
In many European countries, English is the dominant second language taught in schools, not French.
Even if French is learned, many Europeans do not use it regularly, making the claim about speaking it inaccurate.
Studies show that English is the most commonly taught foreign language in European schools, surpassing French.

supporting.text: Not all European countries have French as an official or widely spoken language, such as Germany or Poland.

attacks.text: Not all European countries have French as an official or widely spoken language, such as Germany or Poland.
French is widely taught as a second language in many European countries, increasing its prevalence.
Even if not official, French is commonly used in business and diplomacy across Europe.
The prevalence of French as a second language does not equate to all Europeans speaking it fluently.
Common usage in specific sectors does not mean the general population speaks French.
Many Europeans prioritize learning English over French as a second language.

supporting.text: Europe is linguistically diverse, with many countries having their own native languages (e.g., Spanish, Italian, Dutch).

attacks.text: Europe is linguistically diverse, with many countries having their own native languages (e.g., Spanish, Italian, Dutch).
French is widely taught as a second language in many European countries, making it commonly understood.
Some European countries have French as an official or co-official language, such as France, Belgium, and Switzerland.
Even if French is taught, proficiency varies greatly, and many Europeans do not speak it fluently.
Having French as an official language in some countries does not imply all Europeans speak it, as many regions use other languages primarily.
Studies show that only a minority of Europeans achieve conversational fluency in French as a second language.
In multilingual countries like Belgium, language use is regionally divided, and not all citizens speak French.

supporting.text: Large populations in Europe, such as in the UK or Scandinavia, primarily speak English or Nordic languages, not French.

attacks.text: Large populations in Europe, such as in the UK or Scandinavia, primarily speak English or Nordic languages, not French.
French is widely taught as a second language in many European countries, including the UK and Scandinavia.
The linguistic diversity in Europe does not negate the fact that French is one of the official languages of the European Union.
Despite being taught, French is not the primary language of communication in these regions, and fluency levels vary widely.
The EU's official languages include many others, and French is not universally spoken or understood across all member states.

supporting.text: French is not even the most widely spoken first language in Europe; German and English have more native speakers.

attacks.text: French is not even the most widely spoken first language in Europe; German and English have more native speakers.
French is still widely spoken as a second language in many European countries, making it a common language across the continent.
The claim specifies 'all Europeans,' which includes regions where French is the primary language, such as France and parts of Belgium and Switzerland.
Even as a second language, French is not universally known; many Europeans do not speak it at all.
Regions where French is primary are a minority; most European countries do not have French as a dominant language.
Language education policies in Europe often prioritize English over French, reducing French's prevalence as a second language.
